questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common cause of valvular heart disease in developing countries?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of valvular heart disease in developing countries is rheumatic fever. This 
is mainly due to the repeated infections with rheumatogenic streptococci and inadequate coverage 
of antibiotics. It mainly affects the mitral valve. In developed countries, degenerative or inflammatory processes are the most common cause of 
valvular heart diseases.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the normal range for the mitral valve area in an adult?
questions.explanation: The size of the mitral orifice in a normal adult is 4-6 sq cm. Depending on the area of mitral valve opening (MVA), mitral stenosis can be classified as: • Progressive MS - MVA > 1.5 sq cm • Severe MS - MVA  1.5 sq cm • Very severe MS -  1 sq cm

questions.question:
Question 3: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with mitral stenosis. Which of the following features is 
least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Left ventricular hypertrophy is not seen in mitral stenosis. On the contrary, right ventricle 
hypertrophy is seen. 896 
Sold by @itachibot Mechanism of mitral stenosis (MS): In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium(LA) to 
the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle. When the MVA is <~2 sq cm, blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle, propelled by 
a mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop 
dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc. All these 
conditions: • Increase the rate of blood flow across the mitral orifice, resulting in further elevation of the LA 
pressure • Decrease the diastolic filling time, resulting in a reduction in cardiac output The image below explains the mechanism of mitral stenosis.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 48-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital in view of severe dyspnea. History 
revealed that the dyspnea was exertional initially and later worsened to breathlessness during 
normal daily activities. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The image of the 
autopsy of the heart is shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.explanation: The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 62-year-old woman presents with breathlessness for 5 months. She is unable to carry out 
her daily activities and has difficulty sleeping. On examination, she has a parasternal heave. 
On auscultation, opening snap (OS) is heard followed by a low pitched rumbling diastolic 
murmur. Which of the following findings is suggestive of increased severity of the given 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis. The more severe the thickening, the 
earlier the opening snap occurs in diastole. Hence, the decreased interval between A2 and opening 
snap (OS) indicates increased severity of the stenosis. The auscultatory findings which are suggestive of increased severity of murmur are: • Decreased interval between A2 and OS • Increased duration of the diastolic murmur Loud S1 is seen in the initial stages of MS when the mitral leaflets are flexible. When there is 
further thickening and calcification of the leaflets, they become immobile, and the amplitude of S1 
decreases. Increased severity of the stenosis increases the left atrial pressure. This increase in left atrial 
pressure can increase pulmonary artery pressure which leads to loud P2 on auscultation.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following cardiac chambers is enlarged in mitral stenosis on chest X-ray 
initially?
questions.explanation:
Left atrium (LA) is the first cardiac chamber to get enlarged in mitral stenosis (MS). It is due to 
the pressure overload of LA. It can be appreciated on the lateral and left anterior oblique views. Other radiographic changes seen in MS are straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac 
silhouette, posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA, and Kerley B lines due to 
distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema. Severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension leads to enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right 
ventricle, and right atrium. Left ventricle remains unaffected in isolated MS.

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient with mitral stenosis presented with worsening dyspnea and fatigue which are now 
present at rest. He also complained of a feeling of heavy pounding in the chest with recurrent 
chest pain. You decided to evaluate the patient using echocardiography. When would you 
advise the patient to undergo a valvotomy?

options.d: In all patients who are symptomatic

questions.explanation:
Mitral valvotomy is indicated in symptomatic (NYHA Functional Class II-IV) patients with mitral 
stenosis (MS) with orifice < 1.5 cm2 in normal-sized adults or <1 cm2/m2 body surface area. Treatment of mitral stenosis: • Administration of warfarin in patients with MS who develop atrial fibrillation. • Surgical treatment includes: • Mitral valvotomy: It is done in symptomatic patients whose mitral orifice is less than 1.5 
cm2. This can be either percutaneous mitral valvotomy or open surgical valvotomy. • Mitral valve replacement: This is done in patients whose mitral valve is severely distorted. 899 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 26-year-old woman undergoing evaluation for panic disorder was referred to the physician 
for complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. Detailed history revealed the presence of 
chest pain, which was substernal and not related to exercise. On auscultation, mid-systolic 
clicks were audible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral valve prolapse. It is caused due to the myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve. It may be associated with 
Marfan's syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. It is more common in 
females of the age group of 15- 30 years. Most patients are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with symptoms 
such as palpitations, syncope due to arrhythmias (premature ventricular contractions, ventricular 
tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation), non-specific chest pain, and dyspnea Auscultation reveals mid-systolic clicks. If there is associated mitral regurgitation, a systolic 
murmur might also be heard. The duration of the murmur of MVP decreases on squatting and 
increases on standing. Whereas the duration of the murmur of MR increases on squatting and 
decreases on standing.

questions.question: Question 10: Carvallo’s sign is associated with the murmur of which valvulopathy?
questions.explanation:
Carvallo’s sign refers to the increase in the intensity of systolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation 
with inspiration. During inspiration, the venous return to the heart increases due to the negative intrathoracic 
pressure. This increases the leak from the right ventricle to the right atrium making the murmur 
louder. In general, the right-sided heart murmurs increase in intensity with inspiration and decrease in 
intensity with expiration, while the opposite is true for left-sided heart murmurs. Pulmonic 
ejection sound is the only right-sided acoustic event that decreases in intensity with inspiration.

questions.question: Question 11: The severity of mitral regurgitation can be assessed by:
questions.explanation:
The severity of mitral regurgitation (MR) can be assessed by the wide splitting of the S2. Due to 
severe regurgitation of blood, the pressure in the left ventricle falls rapidly, leading to the early 
closure of the aortic valve. Clinical findings that indicate the severity of MR is: • Reduced cardiac output • Palpable systolic thrill • Palpable S3 • Wide splitting of S2 Note: The intensity of murmur does not always correlate with the severity of the murmur. 
Intensity may be diminished in severe MR caused by LV dysfunction, acute MI and periprosthetic 900 
Sold by @itachibot valve regugitation.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 65-year-old male patient presented with chest pain, exertional dyspnea and syncope. What 
is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the 
normal aortic valve, calcification of congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis are: • Exertional dyspnea - this occurs due to the left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised 
end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to 
elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. • Angina pectoris - it occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied 
myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery. • Syncope - it occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial 
dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

questions.question:
Question 13: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following 
phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur? 891 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic 
stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in 
symptoms, site of murmur, etc. Clinical findings in aortic stenosis: • Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid 
thrill may also be palpated over these arteries. • Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be 
displaced laterally. Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis: • Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified 
and rigid • Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve 
occurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of 
S2. • S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases • Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends 
before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced 
by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver. The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds. 901 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with breathlessness on exertion and chest pain. Auscultation revealed an 
ejection systolic murmur heard best at the base of the heart. Echocardiography showed 
reduced left ventricular ejection fraction and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the 
following features does not signify a severe form of this disease?
questions.explanation:
The above features point to a diagnosis of aortic stenosis. Wide splitting of S2 is not a feature of 
severe aortic stenosis. On the contrary, there might be single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2. Features of severe aortic stenosis are: • Pulsus parvus et tardus • Palpable carotid thrill • Louder and late peaking of systolic murmur • Single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2 • Presence of S3 and S4 heart sounds • Signs of right and left ventricular failure • Left ventricular hypertrophy

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following conditions is not associated with aortic regurgitation?
questions.explanation:
Acute myocardial infarction is not associated with aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation is the backflow of the blood from the aorta to the left ventricle. It may be caused either due to the defect in the valve or defect in the aortic root (dilation of the 
aortic annulus). Conditions that affect valves are: • Congenital • Endocarditis 902 
Sold by @itachibot • Rheumatic fever • Myxomatous (prolapse) • Traumatic • Syphilis • Ankylosing spondylitis Conditions that affect aortic root are: • Aortic dissection • Cystic medial degeneration • Marfan syndrome • Bicuspid aortic valve • Hypertension

questions.question:
Question 16: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. On examination, a 
diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space and pistol shot sound is heard 
over the femoral arteries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of a diastolic murmur along with the pistol shot sound over the femoral is most 
likely to be due to aortic regurgitation. The image below explains the mechanism of aortic regurgitation.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 58-year-old man presented with exertional dyspnea and angina. On examination, the pulse 
was characterized by abrupt distention and quick collapse. Auscultation revealed an early 
diastolic murmur. Which of the following is a feature of this murmur with respect to the likely 
diagnosis in this case?

options.d: Severity correlates with intensity of murmur

questions.explanation:
The given clinical features are suggestive of aortic regurgitation. An early diastolic murmur is a 
high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur. Auscultatory findings in AR are: 903 
Sold by @itachibot • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve • Diminished or absent A2 • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign 
of impaired LV function. • Early diastolic murmur - • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur • Best heard in the left third intercostal space • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate. • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large 
volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following is the criteria for severe aortic regurgitation, in transthoracic doppler 
echocardiography?
questions.explanation:
Regurgitant volume >60mL/ beat is the criteria for severe aortic regurgitation, in transthoracic 
doppler echocardiography (TTE). Doppler echocardiography can be used to assess the severity of aortic regurgitation. According to 
this, AR is considered to be severe when: • Central jet width is more than 65% of left ventricular outflow tract • Vena contracta width >6mm • Regurgitant fraction >50% • Regurgitant volume >60mL/beat • Effective regurgitant orifice >0.3cm2

questions.question:
Question 19: 893 
Sold by @itachibot What is the treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe aortic regurgitation?
questions.explanation:
The treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe AR is aortic valve replacement (AVR). Treatment of aortic regurgitation: • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased 
cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators. • In severe AR, surgery (AVR) is indicated in the following conditions: • The patient is symptomatic. • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic 
diameter is more than 65mm. • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries. 904 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient has enlarged neck veins, hepatomegaly and a holosystolic murmur along the lower 
left sternal margin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is tricuspid regurgitation. Clinical features of tricuspid regurgitation are: • Distended neck veins with prominent c-v waves • Hepatomegaly with systolic pulsations • Positive hepatojugular reflex - the distension of the jugular vein when firm pressure is applied 
over the liver • Blowing holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin

questions.question:
Question 21: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following 
phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
questions.explanation:
The given phonocardiogram is of a pansystolic/holosystolic murmur. It is heard in mitral 
regurgitation (MR), tricuspid regurgitation (TR), and ventricular septal defect (VSD).

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient has a right upper limb BP of 180/95 mm Hg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mm 
Hg. He also has an early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the 
following is least likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.explanation:
A significant difference in blood pressure measured between two arms (>10 mm Hg) may be 
seen in Takayasu arteritis (subclavian artery disease), supravalvular aortic stenosis, aortic 
coarctation, and aortic dissection (all four options). An early diastolic murmur in the right second intercostal space (aortic area) is suggestive of aortic 
regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis (Option A), which involves the part of the aorta distal 
to the aortic valve, is unlikely to cause aortic regurgitation and hence the best answer. 905

questions.question: Question 23: Barlow’s syndrome refers to which of the following?

options.c: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion
options.d: Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria

questions.explanation:
Barlow’s syndrome refers to mitral valve prolapse. Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is also called as systolic click-murmur syndrome, Barlow’s 
syndrome or floppy valve syndrome. It is the most common abnormality leading to primary mitral 
regurgitation. Note: Infantile scurvy is referred to as Barlow's disease. 906 
Sold by @itachibot Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever
